displayed_text: Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: The chemo is every three weeks, but the vitamin C is in high doses and it’s infusion. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, uh, and, as of now, I still think even the placebo equaled yet a dummy infusion. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, so, you come in and maybe get tons of sugar. Um. And, we’re trying to sort out side effects of the Docetaxel, and then we can sort of compare it between the two groups --- is, do people have better PSA responses, longer PSA responses or there is no benefit to adding the vitamin C? Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: Um. So, that’s a reasonable study for ya, but you know, again, you would Patient: Screw a weekend, yeah. About an hour and half of life. Doctor: Um. So, that, you know, again, the vitamin C has to be given here because we’re paying for it. Patient: Right. Doctor: The other study that right now, the-the call that I got interrupted was about your eligibility for a phase one study. Uh, that is a first in human of a brand new drug that we’re evaluating only in prostate cancer. Patient: Okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: Okay, good. Family Member: So how will you know? Doctor: Well I think - Patient: Symptoms. Doctor: - both PSA and scans. We’ll probably plan on doing scans again in three months. Okay. Family Member: His last PSA do you have the results of that? Because we didn’t get uh… Where did you have that done? Doctor: I only have CBC’s from outside, so I think - Patient: I had I had a PSA done. Doctor: - today’s PSA is going to be your one in a long time. Family Member: Okay well he had one… Doctor: Because when they did it in F____ all they did is only blood counts right? Patient: Uh, yeah. Yeah, B___ City.

Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: that’s not uh virus-related but drug related. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: There’s other parts of the body. Any part of your body could get one of these “-itises” —pneumonitis, hepatitis, colitis. So we’re tuned to listen to you and let you, teach you how to tell us right away if there is something going on and then we have to judge fast where we think worried/not worried. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: That’s experimental; we don’t know what the real benefit to someone like you is. We can’t tell you we’re going to make you live longer. Family Member: Mm, hmn. Doctor: But that would be potentially something you could participate in. Right now I would be a little bit worried about putting you on it with these gasping things that I can’t explain- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: because it might affect our ability to get the therapy in. Uhm, we have another study which I, uh - Transformer - we have a first-in-human study of a drug that comes from plum seeds. In laboratory studies it looks like it can attack and kill prostate cancer cells. So this is a study where we’re looking at a drug that now is in I.V. form to see how often does it affect the PSA, how often do you get side effects that we can’t give it to you. So it’s more about the side effects and whether it helps you or not. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Some of the data says that it could help you, but we don’t know. We’ve never given it to enough men. We treat a number of men and if they do okay, then we go to a higher dose.

Patient: I don’t think I’d have any trouble tolerating. Doctor: Yeah. It doesn’t seem like, from everything I’m gathering about this medication, it seems like it’s been easy to tolerate. There may be some infusion reaction or, you know-. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Some occasional side effects, but we’ll be monitoring your blood labs, liver function, kidney function, all of that, every time before we give you that injection. Family Member: So- Doctor: So you’ll be monitored. Patient: So when I do get, when do I get my tickets? Doctor: Well, once, first, you have to sign the consent and do all the screening. Then we can register you and start booking the, the tickets, and whatnot. Patient: Here’s the papers I sign? Doctor: This is not the paper. Doctor: We have to bring you- Family Member: He didn’t care.

Patient: Oh, L___, oh. Could you get me the, his card, or something? Doctor: I’ll give you his phone number, yeah. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. He’s specifically a spine surgeon. I’ve known him for many years. Patient: Oh, I see. Okay. Family Member: Oh. That makes sense. Doctor: He used to be at the D___ and C___. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So now he left and practices here but I know his work, so, (laughter) Patient: Okay. Okay. Okay. Good. Yeah. Family Member: So he has to see a neurosurgeon because I watch a program and they were replacing, putting in, uh, uh, orthopedic surgeon. Doctor: Yeah. So there are some orthopedics who do spine, who focus on spines.

Family Member: It didn’t tell you --- Doctor: No, I wanted to know how much Neanderthal was in me. (Laughs) Doctor: Right, right. Patient: But that’s, uh, not so much the case anymore. That --- Doctor: Or how much – I’ve been watching these alien shows. I wanna learn how much alien Patient: Oh good, good. Doctor: Alien DNA. Patient: My doctor watches the alien shows (laughs) Family Member: That’s everyone. Does that make you feel better. Patient: Okay great, man. I feel great now. I just, I just took the survey “Do I trust my doctor?” I gotta go back and change it. Doctor: Oh, my lord. Doctor: I find it interesting because they, not about the alien part, but they tell you a lot of cool stuff about weird places on earth that you didn’t know about. You’re like, oh, that’s kind of a cool place over there in, you know, Bulgaria or something.

Family Member: I’m hoping. I’m looking for a little light of sunshine. Okay. And then the extra nodule that doesn’t say what that was. It just says it had extended out of one, the one positive node. Right? Doctor: So that’s not a ray of sunshine. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So node looks like that, actually they’re smaller. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And they can get cancer in them and then cancer can grow out of that a little bit. That’s extra nodule extension. Family Member: Um hum and you don’t know what that’s touching other nodes or other areas of the body? Doctor: No it’s just a sign, it’s like a sign like or more aggressiveness. We call it a prognostic factor. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It doesn’t mean that it’s touching something else. Family Member: And do they normally, do you normally just get a sampling of lymph nodes or is there a certain number you see or amount? Doctor: There’s a region that we remove lymph nodes. Family Member: Okay.

Patient: Um hum. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Better than four point two. Right. But you know your scans still show two new spots in your head. Not brain. Skull. Family Member: Right. Uh huh. Doctor: So I feel like something’s definitely about to happen. You know? Break, breakthrough. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Which is why I think the last conversation was on the vaccine therapy, Provenge. So I know we gave, we gave you all that information. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: I’m not sure he gave it to you? Family Member: No. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: No. He did not. Hum.

Patient: So, I’m not sure that that isn’t a progression of some arthritis. Doctor: Yeah. Right. Could be. Patient: Or something. Healthcare Professional: The bone scan didn’t detect anything new in your hip. Nothing new. Doctor: Right Healthcare Professional: Nothing new. Patient: Right. Okay. Doctor: I mean, I think the rise is so small. We know it is just starting to breakthrough. Family Member: Mmm, hmm. Doctor: But, probably can’t definitively prove it right now on scans. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because the scans are so nonsensitive. Patient: Okay.

Patient: So I went again back to the emergency hospital and they made a mistake; they pulled it out. I still couldn’t pee. And I had peeing, but very little at the time. So they said it’s not doing it properly, so they put catheter back in. And they told me they shouldn’t have taken out. So the urologist told me; they should have flushed it and anyway, so. Doctor: So they kept you in overnight that time? Patient: Uh no, no. Doctor: So you were only in and out for what time? Patient: Only in and everything was right. There was only one. I came around three-thirty and by eleven you know I’m home. And I felt okay because then when I started peeing again properly there’s no problem anymore. Family Member: They also took; uh they checked the kidneys. Patient: Yeah, they checked the kidneys; the kidneys were improving, but uh - Doctor: So you were in the hospital once or twice? Patient: Twice. Doctor: Overnight? Patient: No. Let’s say over seven days. Doctor: And you were just in E.R. Patient: I was just E.R.

Patient: I wasn’t aware of- Doctor: Like. No. I think it’s okay. I think K___ has everything. So we’re good. Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright. I just want to double check. You scared the heck out of me last time. So I’m just gonna I don’t know keep an eye on you just a little bit closer - Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: -until I’m confident that I can let you go for three months. Family Member: Right. (Laughter) Doctor: Okay. It’s all good. Don’t run away. I’ll bring back K___ and the nutrition book. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay.

Family Member: You went out on the deck. Patient: No. I’m talking about walking. I’m not talking about that now. Family Member: Oh. Okay. Right. I just wanted to clarify. Patient: But I went out to, uh, to see how, how to walk because sometimes it was difficult walking especially with this leg here. And, uh, I don’t, I don’t know, I had a whole lot of pep in my step- Doctor: Okay. Patient: - going down and coming back, and, uh, my daughter said you don’t seem like you feel anything. I said, no, I feel pretty good there. And, uh, so I do have those particular days, but then I have those days as well. I said, oh, man, when this day going to be over with so I can go to bed tonight Doctor: Is that because of pain that those days are hard for you? Patient: Sometimes it’s, it’s pain, but a lot of the areas that I wasn’t haven’t pain in, uh, not much anymore. My heel on my left side was having a lot of pain that I think I had shared, and, uh, I still have some if I go and overdo it, but other than that, no, my shoulders every now and then. My biggest challenge now is, is getting a good night’s sleep. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And that’s because I’ve tried a number of different ways on how to sleep in the bed. I, I have these pillows that I prop up with a long pillow there, to try to lean up against the back of it so, I, you know, my back is up against the pillow. It works some nights. Some nights it doesn’t work. Doctor: Okay. And so you’re having trouble falling asleep or is it that you fall asleep and then you, you’re waking up with-? Patient: Well, I wake back up. And sometimes if, uh, you know how you try to get in a comfortable position? It’s trying to find that comfortable position for that night.

Patient: Is it - That’s about what, a two hour deal? Doctor: Mm probably longer. I would just spend, I would just block off a half a day because they’re probably gonna put you in that happy place like when you get a colonoscopy happy place. Patient: I am awake during my colonoscopies. I go into twilight. Doctor: You’ll be in twilight, you’ll be in twilight. Patient: Just ‘cause I like to look at the – doctor uh. Doctor: Oh you’re like, you like to actually be awake. Patient: I like - Uh yeah. Doctor: Okayy. Patient: I’m actually looking at the screen. Um… Doctor: Okay. This is – you’re gonna be wore out. Patient: Dr___, Dr____ Doctor: I think you’re gonna be a little bit more out…

Patient: Oh yeah. Doctor: I like stay positive. But you know me to be positive anyway. Patient: So we might want to do a blood test today? Doctor: Yeah, just to get everything on the record here because the last one was obviously August. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Seventeen. Patient: All right, right. Doctor: We have a creatinine from when you did a quick you know CAT scan. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But we’ll need; I’m sure we’ll need the full megillah. Patient: So what I need to just walk down there? Doctor: We may end up drawing it here. OH, OH, somebody’s eavesdropping. Come on in now.

Patient: Nope. Doctor: That’s how you feel? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, so then let’s stay the course. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then I will have ___ follow up with you for next month or I’ll just get the picture be out soon. Patient: Okay. And the Xtandi is, I’m out of refills. So I don’t know if C or you? It was prescribed by her. I forgot to mention to her last time because I Doctor: And uh where do you get that filled at? Patient: Right here. They mail them to me, so I have two weeks left. Patient: No. Doctor: And you’ve already talked to (names person) Patient: No. I gave her everything this morning. She has all the paperwork. Doctor: Okay, do you need anything from me other than that?
